sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Migraine (Acute): initial, 20 or 40 mg ORALLY; may repeat after 2 hours if migraine returns/persists; MAX single dose: 40 mg; MAX daily dose: 80 mg

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• hepatic impairment, severe: use not recommended
  • hepatic impairment, mild to moderate: no dosage adjustment necessary

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• coronary artery vasospasm, including Prinzmetal angina
  • CYP3A4 inhibitors, potent (ie, ketoconazole, itraconazole, nefazodone, troleandomycin, clarithromycin, ritonavir, nelfinavir); concomitant or recent use (ie, within 72 hours)
  • ergotamine-containing or ergot-type agents such as dihydroergotamine or methysergide; concomitant or recent use (ie, within 24 hours)
  • 5-hydroxytryptamine-1 agonists; concomitant or recent use (ie, within 24 hours)
  • hypersensitivity to eletriptan
  • hemiplegic or basilar migraine, current or history; increased risk for stroke
  • hypertension, uncontrolled
  • ischemic bowel disease
  • ischemic coronary artery disease (eg, confirmed silent ischemia, angina pectoris, history of myocardial infarction)
  • peripheral vascular disease
  • stroke or TIA, history of; increased risk for stroke
  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome or arrhythmias associated with other cardiac accessory conduction pathway disorders

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• arrhythmia, (eg, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation) including fatalities, has been reported within hours of use of 5-hydroxytryptamine-1 agonists; discontinue if occurs
  • blood pressure elevation, significant including hypertensive crisis with acute impairment of organ systems, has been reported in patients with or without a history of hypertension after use of 5-hydroxytryptamine-1 agonists; monitoring recommended
  • coronary artery vasospasm (Prinzmetal's angina) may occur in patients with or without a history of coronary artery disease; monitoring recommended in patients at risk
  • cardiac events, serious including acute myocardial infarction and fatalities, have been reported within a few hours of administration in patients with or without known coronary artery disease; consider administration of first dose in a medically supervised setting in triptan-naive patients with multiple cardiovascular risk factors, or in patients at risk who have a negative cardiovascular evaluation and perform ECG immediately after administration; periodic monitoring recommended, particularly with long-term intermittent use
  • cerebrovascular events (eg, cerebral hemorrhage, subarachnoid hemorrhage, stroke), some fatal, have been reported with the use of 5-hydroxytryptamine-1 agonists; exclude other serious neurologic conditions prior to initiating therapy in non-migraineurs and in migraineurs presenting with atypical migraine symptoms
  • coronary artery vasospasm (Prinzmetal angina) may occur in patients with or without history of coronary artery disease; consider administration of first dose in a medically supervised setting in triptan-naive patients with multiple cardiovascular risk factors or in patients at risk who have a negative cardiovascular evaluation and perform ECG immediately after administration; periodic monitoring recommended, particularly with long-term intermittent use
  • hepatic impairment, severe; use not recommended
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, anaphylactoid, and angioedema, have occurred; increased risk in patients with history of multiple allergies
  • medication overuse headache may occur when acute migraine drugs are used for 10 or more days per month; detoxification and treatment of withdrawal symptoms may be necessary
  • pain, tightness, heaviness, or pressure sensations in the chest, throat, neck, or jaw (non-cardiac-related), have been reported; cardiac evaluation recommended in patients with high cardiac risk; discontinue use if occurs
  • serotonin syndrome may occur within minutes to hours of new or increased doses of serotonergic drugs, particularly with concomitant use of SSRIs, serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants, or MAOIs; discontinue use if suspected
  • vasospastic reactions, non-coronary related (eg, Raynaud syndrome, peripheral vascular ischemia, gastrointestinal vascular ischemia and infarction) may occur; if symptoms are observed, rule out vasospastic reaction prior to administering additional doses
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Eletriptan: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (Up to 8%)
  • Neurologic:Asthenia (4% to 10%), Somnolence (3% to 7%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Chest pain (Up to 4%), Coronary artery spasm, Myocardial infarction, Transient myocardial ischemia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction, Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident, Seizure
  • Other:Serotonin syndrome

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Eletriptan has high affinity for 5-HT1 receptor subtypes, more specifically those receptors located on intracranial blood vessels, and acts as a receptor agonist at those sites. Two theories exist to explain the 5-HT1 receptor agonists in migraine headaches: activation of 5-HT1 vasoconstricts intracranial blood vessels and correlates to relief of migraine headaches; activation of 5-HT1 receptors on sensory nerve endings inhibits pro-inflammatory response in the trigeminal system.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral, tablets: time to peak concentration, 2 h
  • Bioavailability: (Oral), approximately 50%
  • Effect of food: (Oral), the area under the concentration-time curve (AUC), and maximum concentration (Cmax) are increased 20% to 30% after a high fat meal

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic; isoenzyme P450 CYP3A4
  • Active metabolites: N-demethylated metabolite; 10% to 20% plasma concentration of eletriptan

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Eletriptan: (normal population) 4 h
  • Eletriptan: (elderly) 4.4 h to 5.7 h
  • Eletriptan: (hepatic impairment) increase in half-life
  • N-demethylated metabolite: 13 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • administer first dose in medically-supervised setting for patients with multiple cardiovascular risk factors
  • do not administer within 24 hours of any ergotamine-containing medication, ergot-type medication, or any other 5-hydroxytryptamine-1 (5-HT1) agonist
  • do not administer within 72 hours of potent CYP3A4 inhibitors including ketoconazole, itraconazole, nefazodone, troleandomycin, clarithromycin, ritonavir, or nelfinavir.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• relief of headache and associated symptoms is indicative of efficacy
  • cardiovascular (CV) evaluation; prior to treatment initiation in elderly, at-risk, or triptan-naive patients with multiple CV risk factors to rule out coronary artery disease or vasospasm; if treatment is initiated, consider ECG upon first use and periodic CV evaluations in long-term intermittent users of eletriptan or in patients with high cardiac-risk who experience vasospasm following administration
  • neurological evaluation; before treatment initiation in patients previously undiagnosed or presenting with atypical symptoms
  • blood pressure; during therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient this drug only treats migraines and will not prevent migraines from occurring.
  • Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as this drug may cause dizziness or somnolence.
  • This drug may cause nausea or asthenia.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of ischemic cardiac syndrome (eg, angina, myocardial infarction, stroke, or TIA).
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of ischemic bowel disease (eg, sudden severe abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea) or peripheral vascular disease (eg, Raynaud syndrome).
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of serotonin syndrome (eg, agitation, hallucinations, tachycardia, hyperthermia, labile blood pressure, hyperreflexia, incoordination, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting).
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of hypertensive crisis.
  • Instruct patient to take a second dose 2 or more hours after the first, if needed, and no more than 80 mg a day.
  • Patient should avoid taking drug within 24 hours of ergotamine-containing medications (eg, dihydroergotamine), ergot-type medications (eg, methysergide), or 5-HT1 agonists.
  • Patient should avoid taking drug within 72 hours of CYP3A4 inhibitors (eg, ketoconazole, itraconazole, nefazodone, troleandomycin, clarithromycin, ritonavir, and nelfinavir).
